facts.text: The two appellants, seeking to appeal against the common judgment and order of the Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench, September 10, 1965, in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution, applied to the Division Bench of the High Court for a certificate under Arts. 132 and 133(1)(a) or (b) and/or (c) of the Constitution.
Their applications were summarily dismissed on December 6, 1965.
The present two appeals consolidated for hearing are by special leave and are against the order refusing certificate.

The appellants and 3 others had, by their several petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution asked that certain notices issued under s. 17(2) of the Act for declaration of lands in excess of the ceilings as surplus and requiring that they be surrendered, be quashed on the ground that the Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceilings on Holdings) Act 1961 (27 of 1961) offended Arts. 14, 19 and 31 and was therefore void under Art. 13.
The Divisional Bench disposed of the five petitions by a common judgment and order on September 10, 1965 dismissing them.
It was held that barring S. 28, the Act was already held to be validly enacted in a decision of the High Court in another petition decided on October 25, 1964.
The earlier case had laid down that the Act was saved by Art. 31-A.
The Divisional Bench also pointed out that the Act was included in the 9th Schedule to the Constitution and enjoyed protection of Art. 31-B. That too was held in yet another petition.
The learned counsel attempted to urge some new grounds but was not allowed to do so. The petitions were dismissed but without costs.

1976 acres of dry crop lands were involved and were likely to be declared surplus and asked to be surrendered and that at a valuation of Rs. 1,000 per acre, the value of the subject matter in the High Court and on appeal to this Court was well over the mark.
The High Court refused the certificate but gave no reasons for the refusal.
Special leave was granted on May 5, 1966.

Since then on April 10, 1968, in State of Maharashtra etc. v. Madhavrao Damodar Patilchand and Ors. etc this Court has held the Act to be intra vires and the Act is also included in the 9th Schedule and is protected by Art. 31-B of the Constitution.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellants were entitled to a certificate under Articles 132 and 133(1)(a), (b) or (c) as of right to appeal the High Court's dismissal of Art. 226 petitions challenging the validity of the Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceilings on Holdings) Act, 1961.
Whether the High Court ought to have granted the certificate given the valuation exceeded Rs. 20,000 and civil rights were affected in exercise of extraordinary original jurisdiction.

petitioner_arguments.text: They were entitled to a certificate as of right as laid down in Ramesh and Anr. v. Seth Gendalal Motilal Patni and Ors.

In view of the decision of this Court in Ramesh case, the certificate ought to have been granted because the order was made in the exercise of extraordinary original jurisdiction in a civil proceeding and the valuation of the claim was well over Rs. 20,000.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 133; Ramesh and Anr. v. Seth Gendalal Motilal Patni and Ors.

petitioner_arguments.text: The appeals satisfied all the tests laid down by this Court in the earlier case.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 133 is wide enough to take in civil proceedings decided in the High Court in the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction provided some civil right of the party is decided.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The appellants before the High Court were attempting to save their property by challenging the validity of the Act and the decision of the Court that the Act was valid directly affected the civil rights of the parties in properties well over the mark in value.

court_reasoning.text: In these circumstances, the High Court could not refuse the certificate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: There is considerable force in the submissions.

court_reasoning.text: We would have seriously considered remanding the case to the High Court for the grant of a certificate but for two things: Special leave was granted on May 5, 1966. Since then on April 10, 1968, in State of Maharashtra etc. v. Madhavrao Damodar Patilchand and Ors. etc this Court has held the Act to be intra vires and the Act is also included in the 9th Schedule and is protected by Art. 31-B of the Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It will be an exercise in futility to ask the High Court to certify the cases when the appeals that will follow must necessarily and inevitably fail.

court_reasoning.text: It is better to save circuitry of action and to dismiss the appeals before us.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dismiss appeals but make no order about costs.

holdings.text: Appellants were entitled to certificate but appeals dismissed as futile since Supreme Court has already upheld the Act as intra vires and protected under Ninth Schedule and Art. 31B.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramesh and Anr. v. Seth Gendalal Motilal Patni and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Laid down entitlement to certificate as of right in civil proceedings under extraordinary jurisdiction where value exceeds Rs. 20,000 and civil rights affected.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Maharashtra etc. v. Madhavrao Damodar Patilchand and Ors. etc
precedents_cited.relevance: Held the Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceilings on Holdings) Act, 1961 intra vires and protected by Ninth Schedule and Art. 31B.

statutes_cited.name: Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceiling on Holdings) Act, 1961 (27 of 1961)
statutes_cited.relevance: Notices issued under s.17(2) for surplus land declaration challenged as Act void; Act held valid barring s.28, intra vires, saved by Art.31A and protected by Art.31B and Ninth Schedule.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions under Art.226 challenging Act's validity; certificate under Arts.132/133 refused by HC; Act protected under 31A/31B/Ninth Schedule.

outcome.summary: The appeals by special leave against the High Court's refusal of certificate under Arts.132/133 are dismissed as futile, since the Supreme Court has already upheld the validity of the Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceiling on Holdings) Act, 1961 in a subsequent decision, rendering any certified appeal inevitable failure. No order as to costs.

key_quotes.text: Art. 133 is wide enough to take in civil proceedings decided in the High Court in the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction provided some civil right of the party is decided.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains scope of Art.133 for writ proceedings affecting civil rights.

key_quotes.text: It will be an exercise in futility to ask the High Court to certify the cases when the appeals that will follow must necessarily and inevitably fail.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for dismissing appeals despite entitlement to certificate.
